description: From economy, from Latin oeconomia, from Ancient Greek οἰκονομία (oikonomía, “the study of the needs”)

entries.meaning: (social sciences) The study of resource allocation, distribution and consumption; of capital and investment; and of management of the factors of production.
examples: Mary studied economics for 5 years before going into banking.
Synonyms: dismal science; see also Thesaurus:economics
